Award.AbstractNarration:
With National Science Foundation support, the Society for American Archaeology will fund training for Native American students and heritage professionals in order to increase the number of qualified Native American and Native Hawaiian individuals participating in science and archaeology.

Since 1998, the SAA has administered the NSF Scholarship for Archaeological Training grant, which funds three Native Americans or Native Hawaiians each year, who are high school seniors, undergraduate students, graduate students, or tribal or Native Hawaiian cultural preservation program personnel, to pursue training in archaeological methods. The NSF support helps champion the SAA's own grants, which include the Arthur C. Parker Scholarship, Undergraduate Archaeology Scholarship, and Graduate Archaeology Scholarship.

To date, the NSF grants to the SAA scholarship program have directly supported 37 Native Americans and Native Hawaiians, representing many communities throughout North America, who would not otherwise have been able to obtain training in archaeological methods and theory, and to carry that understanding back to their Native communities. The NSF award provides meaningful training experiences and complements the SAA's Board-directed efforts to make the archaeological profession more inclusive and diverse.

NSF funding remains vitally important to support training for the growing number of Native American and Native Hawaiian individuals and communities interested in archaeology. Native peoples constitute a fraction of the discipline's professional class- by most accounts less than 1% of the profession. This percentage is woefully inadequate for a discipline that takes as its major focus, and values the participation of, Native peoples. Recognizing this program, the SAA has taken a leadership role in creating this program to provide financial support for Native peoples with an interest in archaeology. This program substantially fulfills the SAA's efforts to build a diverse profession and build bridges between the archaeological and Native communities.

This program's impacts include the new opportunities for Native Americans and Native Hawaiians to bring to their communities a better understanding of archaeology and valuable skills to support community initiatives in heritage research and preservation. As these students become professionals, they expand the discipline's diversity. The scholarship recipients also contribute to breaking down the false dichotomy between "archaeologists" on one hand and "Native people" on the other. Such training provides to tribes an archaeological science foundation for directing preservation and cultural resource programs in accordance with their own goals and values.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 1998 the Society for American Archaeology (SAA) first applied for and was awarded funding from the National Science Foundation (NSF) to support its Native American scholarship program. This program’s main goal is to increase the number of qualified Native American and Native Hawaiian individuals participating in science and archaeology. Since 1998, each year, the NSF Scholarship for Archaeological Training has funded up to three Native Americans or Native Hawaiians, who are high school seniors, undergraduate students, graduate students, or tribal or Native Hawaiian cultural preservation program personnel, to pursue training in archaeological methods, including fieldwork, analytical techniques, class work, and curation. Additionally, the SAA grants its own funds to three additional Native students each year through the Arthur C. Parker Scholarship, Undergraduate Archaeology Scholarship, and Graduate Archaeology Scholarship.


Funding from the NSF has been instrumental in supporting training for the ever increasing numbers of Native American, Native Hawaiian, Native Alaskan, and other Indigenous individuals and communities who have the desire to study archaeology. By most estimates, the percentage of professional archaeologists who come from Indigenous communities is extremely small, less than 1 percent of the profession. This is a remarkable imbalance considering that much of American archaeology focuses on the Native past. In recognition of this problem, the SAA created a scholarship program to support Native peoples who have an interest in archaeology. The program is aligned with the SAA’s desire to build a more inclusive profession.

Scholarship applicants submit an extensive application that includes details about their proposed training as well as information about their relationship to their community. The SAA's Native American Scholarships Committee (NASC) is composed of a chair selected by the SAA Board and up to 12 members. One SAA Board member serves as liaison to the NASC. This committee carefully reviews the applications, and ranks each candidate by evaluating the applicant on past successes, future potential, application completeness, and the application narrative's persuasiveness. Following the SAA protocols for its committees, the NASC members are directed to be fair and evenhanded, and committee members with a personal investment with students or programs are required to recuse themselves. Within one year of their award, recipients are required to write a one-page report to the SAA summarizing their experiences.


The intellectual merits of this program are the expansion of archaeology's knowledge base by including diverse perspectives and experiences. By opening up archaeology to the very communities that most American archaeologists study, we can create more diverse sets of knowledges from which to draw, such as oral tradition, and incorporate new values into heritage management. With the growing contribution of Indigenous peoples to archaeology in recent years, new paradigms have emerged, including participatory, collaborative, and Indigenous archaeologies. These theoretical openings have provided a discursive space to consider the ways in which Indigenous perspectives can expand the discipline's intellectual breadth.


The broader impacts of this program are the opportunities for Native Americans and Native Hawaiians to bring to their communities a better understanding of archaeology and valuable skills to support community initiatives in heritage research and preservation. The scholarship recipients also contribute to breaking down the false dichotomy between archaeologists on one hand and Native people on the other. This kind of training provides to tribes an archaeological science foundation for directing preservation and cultural resource programs in accordance with their own goals and values. Benefits extend to non-Native participants in these same training programs and field schools who gain experience that will help them to better understand the perspectives of Native peoples.


These scholarships benefit the general American public by supporting the development of professional archaeologists who have experience both with the practice of archaeology as a science but also with tribal perspectives and cultural insights. These practitioners will be able to negotiate challenging situations where national interests intersect with scientific and cultural values as in actions that are covered by Section 106 of the National Historic Preservation Act. The greater numbers of Native American archaeologists can result in greater capacity for tribes to work together with agencies and the business community.


Scholarship awardees have used the funding to attend archaeological field schools led by universities throughout the United States and abroad. Students have used funds to support studies in biological archaeology, a field in which there are almost no Native American researchers. And funds have been used to advance research that uses emerging science, such as the application of portable X-Ray fluorescence technology to the question of lithic sourcing of archaeological collections. The work of these scholars is characterized by innovative science grounded in cultural understanding. The Society for American Archaeology is grateful to have this opportunity to work with Native American communities in producing the next generation of professional archaeologists who will continue our exploration into the American past.
